lines:
1956

November 29, 1921.

Ar. S. C. Luk,

224 North Vayne Street,

Angola, Indiana.

My dear Luk:

Thank you for your good letter just received, also for the 
article by Dr. Sun Yet Sen. I shall read the latter with great interest,

for I have been very much interested in the author's career.

I realize keenly what a hard proposition you Chinese boys are

up against at this time and I am sure that we will always be only too 
ready to help you in every possible way. I have already borrowed money

to be used for you and the other Chinese boys, though the Sun brothers

still have a surplus to their credit, and I am confident that in time 
matters will straighten out to the satisfaction of all concerned. I 
don't want you to be unduly worried and despondent because of the plight 
in which you find yourself just now. At the same time, you must realize

of course the hraportance of exercising the greatest care in the expenditure

of all funds at this time, and I know that you will be rosy to economized

in very possible way. Later on, when the sky has cleared and we know 
just where we stand, there will perhaps be no special reason for contain -
king this form of abstinence.

At present it is or the utmost importance

to do so.

I en advising all of the Chinese boys whose funds have been

placed in my hands to follow this advice, and I know that it is being

given by others to the Chinese students in this country who are in their

care.

With very good wish to you, as always, believe me,

Faithfully yours,

Principal.

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Letter thanking Luk for the article by Dr. Sun-Yet Sen. He states that he is ready to help with expenses, but notes that while finances are challenging for Luk, Luk must realize that economizing in every way is important. Stearns adds that he is giving the same advice to all of his fellow Chinese students.
